bibl.title: Lee Fong v. John Sullivan. Petitioner's Brief
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: United States District Court for the District of Washington

div1.ab: IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT, FOR THE NINTH CIRCUIT.
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF LEE FONG FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS.
div1.p: The Petitioner Lee Fong was arrested and detained in the custody of the Chief of Police of the city of Seattle, upon a charge made against him of having violated the provisions of Sections 6 and 7 of Ordinance 710 of the City of Seattle, approved by the Mayor on the 6th day of February, 1886; and which is entitled, "An Ordinance regulating the establishment and maintenance of Public Laundries and Public Washhouses within the limits of the City of Seattle".

Said Section 6 referred to in in language as follows, towit: "Section 6. It shall be unlawful, from and after the passage of this ordinance for any person or persons to establish, maintain, or carry on a laundry within the corporate limits of the City of Seattle, without having first obtained the consent of the common council, except the same be located in a building constructed either of brick or stone and covered with a metal roof." And so much of said Section 7 as provides for the punishment for all violation of provisions of said Section 6, is in language following, towit: "And any person who shall violate any of the provisions of Section 6 of this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished bya fine or not less than Five Dollars nor more than One Hundred Dollars; or by punis imprisonment for not more than thirty days; or by both said fine and imprisonment."

The complaint upon which the petitioner herein was arrested and detained, charges the ofense alleged to have been committed in the language of said Section 6 of said Ordinance; and that said alleged offense of the petitioner is contrary to Ordinance No. 710, towit: Sections 6 and 7 hereinbefore quoted. It will be observed that pursuant to the provisions of said Section 6 of said recited ordinance, the consent of the Council for the establishment, maintainance and carrying on of all laundries within the corporate limits of the City of Seattle, is not required when said laundry is located or to be located in a building constructed either of brick or stone, and covered with a metal roof. Buildings so constructed are exempt from the requirements of said Section of said ordinance; but in the case of a laundry to be carried on in a frame building or other such than is embraced in the exception to said section, the consent of the council is demanded; and that consent is not conditioned upon any reference to the fitness of the building in which a proposed laundry is to be established, for such purpose, nor upon its protection against the dangers of fire or its satisfactory sanatary conditions; but that such consent is dependent entirely on the arbitrary will of council.

So that it follows, that if the person applying for such consent is in all respects entirely worthy and deserving, and that his building, intended for his laundry business, is possessd of every possible sanatary provision; that all precautions and care has been taken to guard against the danger of fire, and in every other respect fitted for the purpose of his business and entirely free from objectionable features of whatever kind, yet not withstanding all this, the Section puts it in the power of council arbitrarily, without any reason and for prejudicial or whimsocal causes, entirely, to withold the required. consent.
This, we contend, is in direct conflict with the provisions of the Constitution of the United States, and especially of the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments thereto.

Fortunately for the petitioner herein, who has expnded practically his entire means on the preperation of the building for his proposed laundry, and that too upon an expressed permit to do so from the Building Inspector of the City of Seattle, the constitutional question involved in this contention has been decided in his favor by the Supreme Court of the United States, as will be shown by a citation of authorities contained in this brief.

The Honorable Court is first referred to the case reported in 13th Federal Reporter, pages 229 and 233; being the case of "In Re Quong," decided by Circuit Court of the District of California in August 1882. In that case Justice Field, who delivered the opinion, held on Writ of Habeas Corpus that "An ordinance which makes it unlawful for any person to establish, maintain or carry on any laundry within certain limits without first obtaining the consent of the Board of Supervisors, which shall only be granted upon the recommendation of not less than twelve citizens and tax payers in the block in which the laundry is proposed to be established, and which punishes by fine or imprisonment for a violation of its provisions, is invalid.
div1.ab:
In Re Wo Lee 26 Federal Reporter 471,
The Circuit Court of the District of California.
div1.p: On January 26 1886, Justice Sawyer in delivering the opinion, refers to the Laundry Ordinance cases in 13 Federal Reporter 229, the first case herein cited, and says: "That after that decision, the Ordinance passed upon therein was amended by omitting the requirement of the assent of twelve citizens and tax payers in the block, but it still prohibited carrying on a laundry business, after complying with numerous monerous conditions, without in addition having first obtained a license,

or permit therefor, duly granted by resolution of Board of Supervisors, and it prescribed no specific conditions, the performance of which should entitle the party to a license or permit, but the license or permit, after performance of all the other prescribed conditions, still depended upon the will of pleasure of the Board of Supervisors. It simply struck out the consent of the twelve tax payers in the block and left it to rest upon the consent of the Board alone, thereby limiting the number of parties to the consent,without abandoning the principle. For this reason in Jom Jong's case, the Circuit Judge thought the objection still remained unobviated. On this point we think he is also sustained by authorities." The quotation is from Judge Sawyer's opinion found on pade 427 of 26 Federal Reporter. After citing a number of cases therein upon the question involved, Judge Sawyer says on page 473 of said case: "If the court was right in those cases, then it seems to us that the ordinance now in question must be void upon similar grounds."

"Section 1 provides that "It shall be unlawful, from and after the passage of this order, for any person, or persons, to establish, maintain or carry on a laundry within the corporate limits of the city and county of San Francisco without having first obtained the consent of the Board of Supervisors, except the same be located in a building constructed of either brick or stone".

In quite a lengthy opinion by Justice Sawyer in the case just mentioned, he argues and holds on pages 474 and 475, "That the ordinance passed upon by him in said case, (and of which the Seattle Ordinance, alleged to have been violated in this case, is a literal transcript, except as to the City and the body whose consent is required,) is unconstitutional and in conflict with the 14th Amendment of the United States Constiution. The Supreme Court of the State of California having, however,

previous to Judge Sawyer's opinion in the case just cited, held in the case of Yick Wo, that the ordinance passed upon by Judge Sawyer was not in conflict with the constitutional provisions; he, Judge Sawyer, in deference to the previous adjudication of the question involved by the Supreme Court of the State, discharged the Writ of Habeas Corpus in the case before him and remanded the petitioner to the custody of the officer having him in charge.

On appeal of the case just cited of Wo Lee from the decision of Judge Sawyer, and also from the judgment of the Supreme Court of the State of California, in the case of Yick Wo, the Supreme Court of the United States, in an opinion delivered by Justice Matters, reversed both cases, that of Yick Wo vs Hopkins, sheriff of the City and County of San Francisco, and that of Wo Lee vs same, and held the California ordinance (which as stated, is precisely like the Seattle ordinance under review, in this case), to be unconstitutional. In the last mentioned cases, towit: of Yick wo vs Hopkins and Wo Lee vs same, reported in 118th United States Supreme Court Reporter from pages 356 to 374, Justice Matthews in the third paragraph of his opinion, speaking of the ordinance referred to, said, "They seem intended to confer and actually do confer, not a discretion to be exercised upon a consideration of the circumstances of each case, but a marked naked and arbatrary power to give or withold consent, not only as to places, but as to persons. So that, if an applicant for such consent being in every was a competent and qualified person, and having complied with every reasonable condition demanded by any public interest, should, failing to obtain the requisite consent of the Supervisors to the prosecution of his business, apply for a redress by the judicial process of Mandamus to require the Supervisors to consider and act upon

his case, it would be a sufficient answer for them to say that the law had conferred upon them authority to withold their assent, without reason and without responsibility. The power given them is not confided to their discretion in the legal sense of that term, but is granted to their mere will. It is purely arbitrarily and acknowledges neither guidance or restraint."

In quite a lengthy opinion on this subject, Justice Matthews in the recited case, held the ordinance, (which as stated, is in language similar to the Seattle ordinance on the subject), to be in violation of the 14th Amendment of the United States constitution, and reversed the decision both of the Supreme Court of the State of Washington, and that of Judge Sawyer of the Circuit Court of California, and directed the discharge of the petitioners from custody and imprisonment.

It is unneccessary for petitioner's council to quote at leangth from the opinion of Justice Matthews in the case just cited, but the full text thereof is respectfully referred to the Honorable Judge passing upon the petition herein; and especiallly to the point made by his Honor Justice Matthews, that though said ordinance on its face be fair, yet in giving to a board of supervisors an arbitrary power, it made it possible for such a board to discriminate and that it is obnoxious to the provisions of the 14th Amendment to the constitution of the United States, and in that it has such a tendency, and possibility; and although in the cases mentioned, Justice Matthews sets forth that such discrimination in the cases before him was actually shown and exercised on the laundrymen, of chinense birth, yet the broad ground upon which he passes his adjudication, is the fact that the ordinance referred to, puts it in the power of a board, to grant or refuse consent arbitrarily.

By a comparison of dates it will be found, that his Honor Judge Hanford, who whilst City Attorney of te City of Seattle, framed Ordinance 710 of that City, which is being passed in review in this case, wrote said ordinance, admittedly copying it from the San Francisco ordinance, after the later had been held by the Supreme Court of California to be invalid, but prior to the adjudication upon appeal, of its unconstitutionality by the Supreme Court of the United States, in the opinion by Mr. Justice Matthews herein last case cited, the Seattle ordinance having been approved February 6, 1886, and the opinion rendered by Justice Matthews on April 14 of the same year.

In the Stockton Laundry case-in re Tie Loy- reported in 26 Federal Reporter 611 to 616 (in which Justice Sawyer delivered the opinion) the syllabus is "A City ordinance that makes it an offense for any person to carry on a laundry where clothes are washed for pay, within the habitable portion of the City is unconstitutional, and that a party who is held in custody for the violation of a city ordinance that is in conflict with the 14th Amendment of the United States Constitution, is entitled to be discharged on Habeas Corpus; and in said case the Court held it to be a violation of the United States constitution within the meaning of Section 733 of the revised statute which provides that the discharge of a person by habeas corpus, who is illedgally held in custody or imprisonment, Said statute giving jurisdiction to the United States District and Circuit Courts to grant such relief. in

In re Sam Kee reported in 31st Federal Reporter 680 to 681, Justice Sawyer held that a city ordinance which makes it an offense to keep a laundry wherein clothes are clensed for hire, within the limits of the larger part of a city, without regard to the character of the structure, or the appliances used for the purpose, or the manner in which occupation is carried on, is unconstitutional on various grounds, and void, and that

"to make an occupation, indispensable to the health and comfort of civilized man, and the use of the property necessary to carry it on a nuisance, by a mere arbitrary declaration in a city ordinance, and suppress it as such, is simply to confiscate the property and deprive its owner of it without due process of law; and that it also abridges the liberty of the owner to select his own occupation, and his own methods in the pursuit of happiness, and thereby prevents him from enjoying his rights, privileges and immunities, and deprives him of equal protection of the laws secured to every person by the constitution of the United," citing the case of In Re Tie Loy 26 Federal Reporter page 611, and Yick Wo vs Hopkins 118 United States Reporter 356, in support of his position upon the reasons therein given, and Justice Sawyer ordered the discharge of habeas corpus of San Kee, the petitioner therein.

Reference is made in the foot note to the last entitled cases, to the various adjudicated cases on the point ruled on the subject, In Re Hong Wah reported in 82 Federal Reporter 623, the District Court of the Northern District of California held, on September 7, 1897, District Judge D. Haven delivering the opinion, that a city ordinance which provides that it should be unlawful for any person to establish, maintain or carry on the business of a public laundry, where articles are washing and clensed for hire, within the City, except in certain designated localities, and declared any such laundry established or carried on in violation of said provision, a public nuisance, and the violation of the ordinance a misdemeanor, punishable by fine or imprisonment, was in contravention of the 14th Amendment of the Constitution of the United States; and that the ownership of property, no matter where located, carries with it the right to use, and to permit the use of ushc property in the prosecution of any legitimate business which is not a nuisance

in itself, and the exclusion of any such lawful business from a particular locality can only be justified upon the ground that the health, safety or comfort of the surrounding community requires such exclusion, and that a public laundry is not a nuisance per se, and cannot be made so by the legislative declaration of a city council; nor can the right of any person to engage in any such useful occupation, not a nuisance per se at such place as he may choose for that purpose, be denied by any law or ordinance, and the court in that case, it being a habeas corpus hearing, discharged the petitioner from his imprisonment.

In re Grice 79 Federal Reporter 627, 633, the Circuit Court Northern District of Texas in a Habeas Corpus hearing, held that even if the writ is not autorized in behalf of a person at large on bail, yet if he surrenders himself, or is surrendered by his sureties, and is in actual confinement, the writ may issue and the Court will not consider an objection, that he was surrendered by collusion with his sureties, and that a Federal Court has the power to grant a writ of habeas corpus in advance of the trials of a person confined on a charge of having committed an offense. It has been, however, stipulated by the counsel for the petitioner and the city attorney in this case, that no advantage shall be taken or question shall be taken or question raised from the fact that after Judge Hanford had granted the rule to show cause in this case, the petitioner Lee Fong was released from custody on bail.

The Court's attention is also respectfully called to the case of Mineapolis Brewing Company vs McGilloway, reported in 104 Feferal Reporter 258, where it was ruled that the constitutionality of a statute is not determined by what has actually been done thereunder, but by what may be done thereunder, but by what may be done by virtue of its provisions.
Applying that doctrine to the case in hand, and it follows

that the fact that under the ordinance for the alleged violation of which the petitioner herein was arrested and imprisoned, a discrimination may be arbitrarily made by the city council of Seattle, of itself, establishes and unconstitutionality of the ordinance.

The case of Harry Fundling vs the City of Chicago reported in Vol. 177 of the United States Supreme Court Reporter, bottom page, 725, relied upon by the City Attorney in this case, as an autority in support of the constitutionality of the ordinance involved herein, will be found upon examination to give no support to the City's contention. The syllabus therein is that "An ordinance giving the mayor power to determine whether a person applying for a license to sell cigarettes, has a good character and reputation and is a suitable person to be intrusted with their sale, but requiring him to grant a license to every person fulfilling these conditions, does not vest in him any arbitrary power to grant or refuse a license, in violation of the provisions of the United States constitution, 14th Amendment, either in regard to the clause requiring due process of law, or in that requiring equal protection of the law.

It will readily be observed that the case referred to is no authority in the case under consideration; the Court itself therein points out the clear distinction between it and that of Yick Wo vs Hopkins 118 United States Reporter 356, cited in behalf of the petitioner. The Court says "The ordinance in question in that case was held to be illegal and to be violation of the 14th Amendment, because with reference to the subject upon which it touched, it conferred upon the municipal authorities arbitrary power, at their will, and without regard to discretion in the legal sense of the term, to give or withold consent as to persons or place for carrying on a laundry without, reference to the compentency of the person applying or of the propriety of the place selected." And the court in this case referring to the Yick Wo case say, "The ordinance in

question here does not grant to the mayor arbitrary power such as mentioned in the above mentioned laundry case. In the case at bar the license is to be issued if the mayor is satisified that the person applying is of good character and reputation and a suitable person to be entrusted with the sale of cigarettes, and that the mayor is bound to grant the license to every person fulfilling these conditions."

A careful examination of the authorities herein cited, it is confidentially contended, will establish clearly the claim made in behalf of the petitioner herein, that the 6th Section of Ordinance No. 710 of the city of Seattle under a writ which he was arrested, is in conflict with both the 5th and the 14th Amendments to te constitution of the United States; indeed the case of Yick Wo vs Hopkins 118 United States has of itself expressly determined and fixed the unconstitutionality of Sections 6 and 7 of Ordinance 710 of the Act City of Seattle, the ordinance adjudicated in said case being as already shown in language identical with the Seattle ordinance, the one being a copy of the other.

As indicated by Justice Matthews in the case of Yick Wo in 118 United States Supreme Court Reporter herein cited, the section held in said case to be unconstitutional and of which the one herein under consideration is a copy, is unconstitutional, in that first it discriminates between buildings for laundry purposes, which are constructed of brick or stone, and those that are not so constructed; and secondly, between such as are not so constructed but obtain the consent of the Board, and those who fail by the arbitrary will arbitrary will of the Board to obtain such consent; and the objection theretio was founded upon the fact that said ordinance makes it possible for the body whose consent was necessary to withold such consent without reason and without conditiion, and that under its provisions one class of persons could
arbritarily be given such consent, and another class be refused the same.

It was the possibility of a municipal body of men withholding consent arbitrarily, which was pronounced to be unconstitutional. The Supreme Court of the United States in the case mentioned, made its ruling upon the provisions of the 14th Amendment to the constitution independently of and without reference to the fact that the petitioners for habeas corpus were Chinamen. The adjudication in principle would have been the same if the petitioners had been of the white or Caucasion race. The unconstitutionality of the ordinance in that case as also in the case at hand, made no mention of the ract or nationality to which the person maintaining a laundry belongs.

But in addition to the ordinance passed upon being held to be in conflict with the 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution, it was held to also be, in the application to the case of the petitioner, a violation of the treaty between the United States and the Empire of China, in that, the facts in the case show that the ordinance was being used in such manner as to be a violation of said treaty. The petitioners in that case were Chinamen, as he is also in the case now being considered, and as, in the application of the ordinance to the petitioners in the Yick Wo case, it was held to be not only in conflict with the United States constitution but also a violation of the treaty between the United States and China, so in like manner, the petitioner said Lee Fong, for a writ of habeas corpus in this case, alleges that his arrest and confinement under the 6th and 7th sections of ordinance No. 710 of the City of Seattle, is in conflict with both the constitution of the United States and the treaty with China.
In support of the last mentioned allegation, the Court's attention is especially called to the following facts in this case,

First, that when an application was made to the city of Seattle for a permit to change the premises Number 1410 East Fir Street, into a laundry, the builders specifications for said change which was expressly designated" to be for LAUNDRY purposes" were examined by the Building Inspector and duly approved and a permit granted, authorizing the proposed change of said premises, no reference was made in said specifications to the fact that the laundry was to be conducted by a Chinaman; it being simply stated, to be "for a LAUNDRY;" that at the same time, that said laundry permit was granted, the Health Officer of the City of Seattle, after inspecting the same specifications on June 18th 1802, gave his official certificate in which he said, "Permission is given John Miller to build a laundry at 1410 East Fir Street, he having complied with the City ordinance," the said John Miller, a white man, being the owner of the premises referred to, and no mention having been made at the time of the fact that the petitioner LEE FONG, herein, or any other Chinaman, was, as the lessee of said premises from said Miller, to conduct said laundry. Pursuant to these respective permits the petitioner Lee Fong expended upwards of $600. in having made according to said specifications, the necessary changes, whereby said premises were converted into a building suitable for laundry purposes, and at the conclsion of the work of making such changes in said premises te Health Officer of the City of Seattle, towit: on August 2nd, 1902, gave a certificate as follows: "This is to certify that I inspected the premises at 1410 East Fir Street, and found them properly and sufficiently drained; and that proper arrangemtns as to the sanatary conditions has been complied with". And on July 30th 1902, the City Inspector of Plumbing, for said City certified that the plumbing in said building had been inspected, completed and found to be in accordance with the ordinance of the City of Seattle.

That notwithstanding the facts herein last mentioned and set forth certain persons, at, or about the time when the said premises had been converted into a laundry building at the expense herein metioned to the petitioner herein, petitioned the Common Council of the city of Seattle, setting forth that they were legal voters and resided in the vicinity of said premises, and protesting against having a "CHINESE LAUNDRY"; designating it as stated, "A CHINESE LAUNDRY" and asking the Council to withhold their consent for the same. This petition was endorsed "A remonstrance against locating of "A Chinese Laundry" at No. 1410 East Fir Street; was referred to the Committee of the Councils, who reported withot having given the petitioner herein a hearing, recommending that the Council refuse to grant its consent to said laundry; which report was adopted by the said Council, whereby the petitioner Lee Fong was refused to consent of the Council to establish and maintain his proposed laundry, after having expended nearly $600. under a permit from said City..

Secondly: That upon said petitioner's counsel applying to one of the committee of said Council, who had reported adversely to the granting of the Council's consent to such laundry, asking for a reconsideration of the council's action in the premises, he was informed by said committeeman of said Council, that he would never under any circumstances or conditions give his consent for establishing of "A Chinese Laundry" at the locality mentioned, emphasizing his objection as being to a granting of a CHINESE LAUNDRY thereat.

Thirdly: That when said petitioner's counsel applied to the Chief of the Fire Department of the City of Seattle for his inspection of the premises referred to, so as to determine whether or not it had been so constructed as to provide against dangers from fire, said

Chief of Fire Department in like manner expressed himself strongly in opposition to the granting of a permit for a laundry, to be conducted in the premises mentioned by a Chinaman;" that afterwards, however, upon being told that it was his duty to make said inspection, he complied with said request, and afterwards stated upon oath that the only feature of the building which he regared as involving any risk from fire was the fact that the gront of a cookstove in said premises had not before it upon the floor a zinc protection, and some objection to the brick work at the entrance to the said stove; that the fact is, that said cookstove was in no manner essential to, or any part of the laundry arrangements of said premises, yet, nevertheless, the petitioner Lee Fong placed upon the floor in front of said stove ample covering of zinc, fastened to said floor, adjusted the brick in the entrance to said stove, so as to meet fully the objections of the Chief of Fire Deparment. That the having fully met the objections of the Chief of Fire Department, and made the part he had objected to entirely safe against fire, said Chief of Fire Department was asked to again inspect said premises so as to determine the satisfactory condition thereof; he, the said Chief of Fire Department entirely neglected and refused to make said inspection. That is was after all this was done, and said premises was securely arranged both in a sanatary point of ciew and against danger from fire, he, the petitioner, being engaged in his business of a laundryman on said premises, was arrested, charged with violation of the provisions of Sections 6 and 7 of ordinance 710 of the City of Seattle. Hence it is claimed that petitioner's arrest and imprisonment was in violation both of the constitution of the United States and the treaty with China.

It being manifest from the facts stated, that the real objection to the granting of council's consent for the maintenance of said laundry was the ascertainment of the fact that it was to be conducted by a Chinaman. Hence, it is claimed that a discrimination was

made against Lee Fong, the petitioner in this case, for no other reason than that he is a Chinaman, it thus being, like the case of Yick Wo ruled by the Supreme Court of the United States in 118 U. S. Reports, a violation of the treaty within China. The primary and chief contention is, however, that the ordinance is itself unconstitutonal and that of itself entitles the petitioner to his dischaarge under habeas corpus, to say nothing of the infringement by said arrest and confinement of the provisions of the Chinese treaty.

After completing the foregoiing, the brief of respondent was received. The position that Section 6 of the Seattle ordinance No 710 must be continued together with Section 2 and 3 or in conditioned upon them, in for the very obvious reason that even with the provisions of Section 2 and 3 being literally complied with, Section 6 of this the council the power to certified to consent, notwithstanding such compliance; nor does it appear nor can it be claimed that in the case of the petitioner Lee Fong, the action of the council in reference its consent was upon and, of or relation to Sections 2 and 3, nor was the charge aforesaid petitioner made reference to Section 2 and 3
Respectfully, submitted by
div1.ab: J M Wiestling Attorney for Petitioner
In the United States Circuit Court FOR THE 9TH DISTRICT
In the matter of the application of Lee Fong for a writ of Habeas Corpus
Received Copy of petitioner Brief this `17th day of Sept 1902
